Hello Chris,

Thank you for your patience regarding this case.

We have received an update from our R&D team, that they have checked the current logs. This time the EPP client receives the list of excluded network shares. Going forward, there is a lot of scanning here, but all the files scanned are from "C:tempGBSDownload"and not from network share like in the previous set of logs.

Moreover, they decrypted the database with the policies and it seems that WinSCP is monitored in the CAP policy. In this case, network share whitelist will not apply anyway.
As long as the file is transferred through a monitored application, network share whitelist is ignored. If not, one could use network share as a "proxy" to exfiltrate any data outside the company.
For example, the user has a confidential file on the local machine. Theoretically transferring it through a browser is blocked by EPP. But if the user copies the file on the network share (which is whitelisted) he can then upload the file, through the browser from that location (again, because the location it is whitelisted). So this is the reason why Network Share whitelist doesn't apply for transfers made by monitored apps.
The reason why Network Share whitelist was added was to give the user the possibility to browse the network share, view/open files, copy them to the local machine, but that's all, he should not be able to actually transfer them outside the company if they contain confidential info.

Finally, in the logs they see a file being scanned and blocked by the EPP client. The reason the file is blocked is the fact that WinSCP is monitored in the CAP policy and the file is being handled (read) by WinSCP. 

Please test without the WinSCP exit point enabled and also with the policy action set to report only.

Looking forward for your response.

Hello Chris,

Thank you for your patience regarding this case.

We have received an update from our R&D team, that they have checked the current logs. This time the EPP client receives the list of excluded network shares. Going forward, there is a lot of scanning here, but all the files scanned are from "C:tempGBSDownload"and not from network share like in the previous set of logs.

Moreover, they decrypted the database with the policies and it seems that WinSCP is monitored in the CAP policy. In this case, network share whitelist will not apply anyway.
As long as the file is transferred through a monitored application, network share whitelist is ignored. If not, one could use network share as a "proxy" to exfiltrate any data outside the company.
For example, the user has a confidential file on the local machine. Theoretically transferring it through a browser is blocked by EPP. But if the user copies the file on the network share (which is whitelisted) he can then upload the file, through the browser from that location (again, because the location it is whitelisted). So this is the reason why Network Share whitelist doesn't apply for transfers made by monitored apps.
The reason why Network Share whitelist was added was to give the user the possibility to browse the network share, view/open files, copy them to the local machine, but that's all, he should not be able to actually transfer them outside the company if they contain confidential info.

Finally, in the logs they see a file being scanned and blocked by the EPP client. The reason the file is blocked is the fact that WinSCP is monitored in the CAP policy and the file is being handled (read) by WinSCP.

Please test without the WinSCP exit point enabled and also with the policy action set to report only.

Looking forward for your response.

Hello Chris,

Thank you for your patience regarding this case.

We have received an update from our R&D team, that they have checked the current logs. This time the EPP client receives the list of excluded network shares. Going forward, there is a lot of scanning here, but all the files scanned are from "C:tempGBSDownload"and not from network share like in the previous set of logs.

Moreover, they decrypted the database with the policies and it seems that WinSCP is monitored in the CAP policy. In this case, network share whitelist will not apply anyway.
As long as the file is transferred through a monitored application, network share whitelist is ignored. If not, one could use network share as a "proxy" to exfiltrate any data outside the company.
For example, the user has a confidential file on the local machine. Theoretically transferring it through a browser is blocked by EPP. But if the user copies the file on the network share (which is whitelisted) he can then upload the file, through the browser from that location (again, because the location it is whitelisted). So this is the reason why Network Share whitelist doesn't apply for transfers made by monitored apps.
The reason why Network Share whitelist was added was to give the user the possibility to browse the network share, view/open files, copy them to the local machine, but that's all, he should not be able to actually transfer them outside the company if they contain confidential info.

Finally, in the logs they see a file being scanned and blocked by the EPP client. The reason the file is blocked is the fact that WinSCP is monitored in the CAP policy and the file is being handled (read) by WinSCP. 

Please test without the WinSCP exit point enabled and also with the policy action set to report only.

Looking forward for your response.
